subject: Re: [junit] Re: Test Grouping/Partitioning
msgSnippet: ... That s not quite what I m thinking, but it s closer. Certainly, I d be shocked to see 14 hours of fast tests, but even 14 hours of slow tests on a single
messageBody:
Bradley, Todd wrote:

> JB wrote:
> > That last bit probably sounded more negative than you
> > intended it to, so I won't take it negatively or personally.
>
> Please don't. My point is just that I suspect you are
> only thinking of JUnit-based unit tests. And I would
> agree that 14 hours of unit tests seems pretty weird.

That's not quite what I'm thinking, but it's closer. Certainly, I'd be
shocked to see 14 hours of fast tests, but even 14 hours of slow tests
on a single project is out of the ordinary. I can't envision a single
project that big. I'd want to ask the people on that project two questions:

1. Why such reliance on slow tests?
2. Should we break this up into about four subprojects?

> But we're running JUnit-based system and acceptance
> tests. In my experience 14 hours of automated system
> testing isn't that unusual for a reasonably large and
> complex software system.

I agree it isn't unusual (in the sense that it happens), but I would
want to look for improvement.

> Are they all valuable? Yes, I think so. They all have
> caught or could catch bugs. In fact, if we had time,
> we would write more tests that would take even longer
> to run, since I don't think we have the test coverage
> I'd like.

Is it really a good idea to have a test suite so long that you can't run
it overnight between when people leave for work and when they come back
in the morning? How do you do a daily build?

> As far as the speed of feedback for 14 hour tests, again
> these are system ("QA") type tests. Comparing a 2 day
> feedback cycle to a 6 week feedback cycle (which is what
> we've had on past projects) the 2 days is obviously a
> monumental step forward.

No question there. If you've managed to reduce the feedback cycle from 6
weeks to 2 days, then that's great work. Still, I find a 2-day cycle
quite long. I imagine you have bigger problems to face right now, so
you're right to face them and not this one, but all things being equal,
I wouldn't be satisfied with a 2-day cycle, and I certainly wouldn't
design JUnit to optimize for the case of the 2-day test cycle.

But that's great work. I'm impressed. Have you written about what you do
differently between the 6-week cycle and the 2-day cycle? I'm sure
people would like to read about that.

Take care.
